content.html:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.
  1. The following quadratic expressions all define the same function.
  • \((x+5)(x+3)\)
  • \(x^2+8x+15\)
  • \((x+4)^2−1\)

Select three statements that are true about the graph of this function.

  • The \(y\)-intercept is \((0, -15)\).
  • The vertex is \((-4, -1)\).
  • The \(x\)-intercepts are \((-5, 0)\) and \((-3, 0)\).
  • The \(x\)-intercepts are \((0, 5)\) and \((0, 3)\).
  • The \(x\)-intercept is \((0, 15)\).
  • The \(y\)-intercept is \((0, 15)\).
  • The vertex is \((4, -1)\).

Answer: The vertex is \((-4, -1)\), the \(x\)-intercepts are \((-5, 0)\) and \((-3, 0)\), the \(y\)-intercept is \((0, 15)\).

  1. The following expressions all define the same quadratic function.
  • \((x−4)(x+6)\)
  • \(x^2+2x−24\)
  • \((x+1)^2−25\)
  1. What is the value of the \(y\)-coordinate of the \(y\)-intercept \((0, \_\_\_)\) of the graph of the function?

Answer: -24
The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-24)\).

  1. Select two \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.
  • \((6, 0)\)
  • \((-4, 0)\)
  • \((-6, 0)\)
  • \((5, 0)\)
  • \((4, 0)\)

Answer: \((-6, 0)\), \((4, 0)\)

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph?

Answer: -1

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph?

Answer: -25

  1. Is this an accurate graph of the function?

  • Yes
  • No

Answer: Yes
The \(x\)-intercepts, \(y\)-intercept, and vertex are plotted accurately.

  1. Here is one way an expression in standard form is rewritten into vertex form.

Original expression
\(x^2−7x+6\)

Step 1
\(x^2−7x+(-\frac{7}{2})^2+6−(-\frac{7}{2})^2\)

Step 2
\((x−\frac{7}{2})^2+6−\frac{49}{4}\)

Step 3
\((x−\frac{7}{2})^2+\frac{24}{4}−\frac{49}{4}\)

Step 4
\((x−\frac{7}{2})^2-\frac{25}{4}\)

  1. In Step 1, where did the number \(-\frac{7}{2}\) come from?
  • It is the substitute value for \(x\).
  • Every term in the expression was divided by 2.
  • It is half of -7 being squared.
  • Only the non-linear term was divided by 2.

Answer: It is half of -7 being squared.

  1. In Step 1, why was \((-\frac{7}{2})^2\) added and then subtracted?
  • It is added to complete the square. It is subtracted to keep the value of the expression unchanged.
  • It is subtracted to complete the square. It is added to keep the value of the expression unchanged.
  • It is added to complete the square. It is subtracted to change the value of the expression.
  • It is subtracted to complete the square. It is added to change the value of the expression.

Answer: It is added to complete the square. It is subtracted to keep the value of the expression unchanged.

  1. What happened in Step 2?
  • The expression is subtracted to keep the value of the expression unchanged.
  • The expression, which is a perfect square, is written as a squared expression.
  • The expression, which is not a perfect square, is written as a squared expression.
  • The expression is added to keep the value of the expression unchanged.

Answer: The expression, which is a perfect square, is written as a squared expression.

  1. What happened in Step 3?
  • The quadratic term is written as a fraction so that it has a common denominator, which makes it easier to subtract.
  • A random term was added to complete the square.
  • The linear term is written as a fraction so that it has a common denominator, which makes it easier to subtract.
  • The constant term is written as a fraction so that it has a common denominator, which makes it easier to subtract.

Answer: The constant term is written as a fraction so that it has a common denominator, which makes it easier to subtract.

  1. What does the last expression tell us about the vertex of the graph of a function defined by this expression?
  • The vertex of the graph is at \((-6\frac{1}{4}, \frac{7}{2})\).
  • The vertex of the graph is at \((\frac{5}{2}, -\frac{5}{2})\).
  • The vertex of the graph is at \((\frac{7}{2}, -6\frac{1}{4})\).
  • The vertex of the graph is at \((\frac{5}{2}, -6)\).

Answer: The vertex of the graph is at \((\frac{7}{2}, -6\frac{1}{4})\).

  1. Enter the missing number, including the sign, for the expression when \(d(x)=x^2+12x+36\) is written in vertex form.

\(d(x)=(x\_\_\_)^2\).

Answer: +6

  1. Enter the missing numbers, including the signs, for the expression when \(f(x)=x^2+10x+21\) is written in vertex form. \(f(x)=(x + \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;} )^2 \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;}\)
  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in the place of the letter a?

Answer: +5

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, for the letter b?

Answer: -4

  1. Enter the missing numbers, including the signs, for the expression when \(g(x)=2x^2−20x+32\) is written in vertex form. \(g(x)= \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;} (x + \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;} )^2 \underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;}\)
  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter a?

Answer: +2

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter b?

Answer: -5

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter c?

Answer: -18

  1. Enter the missing numbers, including the signs, for the expression when \(h(x)=(4x-3)^2\) is expanded to standard form. \(h(x)= ( \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;}\; x )^2 + 2 ( \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;}\; x)(-3) + ( \underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;} )^2\)
  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter a?

Answer: +4

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter b?

Answer: +4

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter c?

Answer: -3
